thread.title: The grazier who rounds up sheep with flying 'pumpkin'
thread.title_full: The grazier who rounds up sheep with flying 'pumpkin'

author: Cherie von Hörchner
title: The grazier who rounds up sheep with flying 'pumpkin'
text:
By Cherie von Hörchner Posted February 20, 2017 12:51:51 Map: Broken Hill 2880 
Having a plane makes life easier when you live on a large outback property. 
Checking water points, fences and hunting feral pests can take hours or even days depending on how much country needs covering. 
Luke Mashford lives on Katalpa Station, 240 kilometres north-east of Broken Hill, and says his sporty recreational Foxbat, nicknamed Pumpkin, makes it easier to manage his livestock. 
"The country we've got here is very open … big flats and not so much scrub," he said. 
"We just wanted to do something different and we spoke to a quite a lot of other people who've had Foxbats. 
"The stability, vision, reliability — all the stuff you'd probably want for a plane — it ticked all the boxes for us." 
Mr Mashford said the helicopter-pod cockpit made it easier to spot livestock on his 217 hectares of undulating saltbush country. 
"They're pretty renowned for their vision," he said. 
"The see-through doors come in handy with chasing sheep … it's amazing." 
Mr Mashford said having a brightly-coloured plane helped station hands on the ground keep track of his whereabouts when working in tandem. 
"It was meant to be an Australian gold colour but the paint shop in the Ukraine had a hiccup and it came out this beautiful pumpkin orange," he said. 
"They sent a few photos over to us and we thought: 'Why respray it yellow? Let's leave it'." 
"We had a good look around at a few other models, as my wife's from a Cessna-based family, so going away from a Cessna is like changing your breed of cattle." 
Mr Mashford's interest in learning to fly had been simmering for a long time. 
"It's always been a bit of an interest," he said. 
"We're just lucky enough to get into a position now with the place and stock numbers getting up. 
"It makes it easier to manage rather than relying on more and more staff," he said. 
"We can do a lot more in-house — that's definitely paid off. 
"The way you manage a place changes a little bit too, as you've got a bird's eye view of anything. You can definitely keep a better eye on what's going on around you, which is great. 
"And, like I said, I've always had an interest in flying and the timing was right for us to give it a go."
